title: How are stationary waves periodic in space? - Quora

response.answer_text: A stationary wave is a wave which oscillates in time but whose peak amplitude profile does not move in space. A periodic wave is a wave which revises its path after an interval of time. Stationary waves are always periodic in nature and they don't entirely depends upon the medium of propagation. So their won't be affected not much in whatever space they are.

Stationary Waves appear to be stationary only because such waves move with velocity exactly equal to and direction exact opposite to that of the medium. But all waves in nature are periodic and so are the Stationary Waves else they cannot be considered as waves.
